summary.seg: This manuscript of the Pupilla Oculi by de Burgo, John, fl. 1370-1398 John Borough John de Burgo (fl. 1370–1398) is a pastoral handbook intended for parish priests. It summarises the church’s penitential and sacramental laws so that they could be understood and applied in practice. The text is derived from the Oculus sacerdotis by William of Paull or de Pagula (fl. early fourteenth century).

De Burgo divided his work into ten parts. These are: I) The sacraments in general; II) Baptism; III) Confirmation; IV) The Eucharist; V) Penitence and sentences of excommunication; VI) Extreme unction; VII) Holy orders; VIII) Marriage; IX) Tithes, sanctuary, wills, clerical residence, and similar matters; and X) Practical theology, including the Ten Commandments, the seven deadly sins, and works of mercy. Trinity Hall’s copy ends during part 8.

Pupilla Oculi was likely written between 1380 and 1385, when for part of that time John de Burgo was Chancellor of the University of Cambridge. Some forty manuscript copies survive. Cambridge was an important centre for the production and dissemination of Pupilla Oculi throughout the 15th century.

msItem.title: Pupilla Oculi
msItem.author: Johannes de Burgo
msItem.incipit: 1r Humane nature iam senescente mundo de cursu temptoris [sic] continue vergens

foliation.p: Modern pencil foliation at the top right hand corner

layoutDesc.layout:
Double columns of 41 written lines 192 136
Ruled in plummet

decoNote.p: One illuminated floriated initial with gold, red and blue (f.2v), which forms three sides of a page border.
Paragraphs marked by blue initials with red penwork flourishing.
Alternating 1-line red and blue initials throughout.

additions.p: The flyleaf (recto) some constitutions and another note in a small hand. Added drawings of a man’s head in margins throughout

binding.p: Late 20th century native dyed red Nigerian goatskin, over pasteboards by Cambridge Colleges Conservation Consortium. Preserved 19th century previous binding, of brown calfskin over pasteboards.

recordHist.source: Description draws on M.R. James(1907). A descriptive catalogue of the manuscripts in the library of Trinity Hall.

James, M. R. (1907). A descriptive catalogue of the manuscripts in the library of Trinity Hall. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, p. 36.
Kelly, Henry Ansgar. (2008). ‘Penitential Theology and Law at the Turn of the Fifteenth Century’, in Abigail Firey (ed.), A New History of Penance, Leiden, Brill, 2008, 239-317.
